learning_outcomes.description: Develop a broad understanding of human evolution.
Develop a general understanding of human and other primate anatomy.
Develop laboratory skills for the study and critical analysis of issues in human evolution.
Understand the diverse sources of evidence that contribute to our understanding of human evolution (e.g., archaeology, palaeontology, geology, genetics, primatology, ethnography).

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, students must develop a portfolio of hominin and great ape fossil anatomy illustrations that accurately reflect the important features present on each specimen. Students will select from four grades of taxa related to early human evolution that will be covered in the first five weeks of the course. For each taxa, students must draw and label the skeletal remains that are present from a list provided on Blackboard Ultra (e.g., cranium and mandible, femur, humerus). Each fossil specimen needs to be drawn (either physically and then scanned, or digitally with software such as Adobe Illustrator) in at least two different views - anterior and lateral (but more is acceptable) with a scale for reference. Each feature label will include information about the importance of the feature in terms of human evolution and changes in the fossil record. A short description (~250 words) of the grade must also be included, with additional information about the descriptions provided on Blackboard Ultra.

You will have time available in the second hour of each session to examine the physical casts in the teaching laboratory. You can use illustrations from the readings as well as 3D models available online through websites such as SketchFab.com. The illustrations must be either free-hand drawings or outlines of the fossil specimen -- labelling photographs or published illustrations is NOT sufficient. The portfolio will be submitted as either a Word document or PDF online through Turn-it-in by the due date and time. 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard Ultra for this course. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: This will be a 1 hour in class practical exam consisting of 30 object-based, short answer, multiple choice, image based, or true/false questions. More details will be given in class.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The exam will take place during class time
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date: The task will be held in your regular practicals/workshops in weeks 12 and 13 (22nd May and 29th May 2026).
assessments.task_description: The task will be held in practicals weeks 12 and 13. You will be scheduled a 10-minute time slot to discuss an article relevant to your essay. You will be required to explain the content and conclusions of the article and discuss how the article will support some of the claims you will make in your essay.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this assignment you will be provided with four essay topics to choose from relating to a key concept in human evolution.

Task: The Research Essay is to be approximately 1,500 words in length and is worth 30% of your final mark. It should be developed as a response to a specific research question in human evolution. Four essay topics relating to a key concept in human evolution will be provided. If you would like to develop your own topic, discuss and confirm your specific research question with the course co-ordinator.

The research question should be stated clearly as part of the title of your essay. The essay should be based on original reading and research in the relevant palaeoanthropological, archaeological and palaeoenvironmental literature, with at least 8 references in your bibliography. As this is an essay assessment, your examination of the topic should have all the elements of an essay including an introduction, conclusion, and thesis statement.

Referencing style: Students must use Chicago style for references (footnotes) and bibliographies: http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/tools_citationguide/citation-guide-1.html

Word Limits: A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (1,500 words) is acceptable. Word count does not include bibliography. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

AI: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.  Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub. 

Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard Ultra for this course.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
